hints.content:
###The Strategy 

When multiplying matrices, we should find each entry of the resulting product matrix separately.

To find entry $(i,j)$ of the resulting product matrix, we calculate the vector *dot product* of row $i$ of the first matrix and column $j$ of the second matrix. [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
In general, vector dot product is an operation that takes two vectors of equal dimensions and returns a single real number.

For any two $n$-dimensional vectors, $\vec{v}=(v_1, v_2, ..., v_n)$ and $\vec{u}=(u_1, u_2, ..., u_n)$, their dot product $\vec{v}\cdot\vec{u}$ is defined as follows.

>$\vec{v}\cdot\vec{u}=v_1\cdot u_1+v_2\cdot u_2 +...+v_n\cdot u_n$

For example, for $\vec{v}=(a,b)$ and $\vec{u}=(c,d)$, we have $\vec{v}\cdot\vec{u}=a\cdot c+b\cdot d$.

###Finding $\text {H}_{1,1}$ 

$\text{H}_{1,1}$ is the dot product of the first row of $\text{B}$ and the first column of $\text{D}$.

$ \text {H}=\left[\begin{array}{rr}\maroonC{1} & \maroonC{4} \\ 1 & 3\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{rr} \maroonC{4} & 3 \\ \maroonC{0} &  -1\end{array}\right]$

Therefore, this is the appropriate calculation of $\text{H}_{1,1}$.

$\begin{align}\text{H}_{1,1}&=(1,4)\cdot(4,0)\\\\
&=1 \cdot 4 + 4\cdot 0\\\\
&=4
\end{align}$

The other entries of $\text{H}$ can be found similarly.
